Description: Cast figure of the goddess Isis in copper alloy; depicted standing with both arms forwards; start of wings visible below her arms; wearing a tripartite wig and a long dress; start of a crown on her head; hands, forearms and feet missing; very corroded.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Town (Naukratis), House of 'cache of bronzes'
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by The Petrie Museum of Egyptian Archaeology. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

This type of Isis is unique in the corpus of bronzes from Naukratis. It was discovered in the cache of bronzes in a building located in the southern part of the town (Petrie 1886, 41-42). The cache was probably made around the late 5th-early 4th c. BC, but some bronzes from this cache could be earlier in date (Masson 2015). Bronzes representing members the Osirian triad – formed by Isis, Osiris and Harpokrates, are conspicuous in Late Period and Ptolemaic bronze votive deposits all over Egypt. Statuettes of winged Isis, however, belong to a rare type (Weiss 2012, 245-247, Pl. 36d-f, Typ 139). Bar one example from Sais, a few other examples originated from the Memphite region (Weiss 2012, 701-702). Masson, A. 2015, ‘Cult and Trade. A reflexion on Egyptian metal offerings from Naukratis’, in D. Robinson and F. Goddio (eds), Thonis Heracleion in Context, Oxford Centre for Maritime Archaeology Monograph 8, Oxford, 71-88. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Weiss, K. 2012, Ägyptische Tier- und Götterbronzen aus Unterägypten: Untersuchungen zu Typus, Ikonographie und Funktion sowie der Bedeutung innerhalb der Kulturkontakte zu Griechenland, Ägypten und Altes Testament 81.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (MB.136) (phase 3)
